title: 108_s1055
content: Credit for qualified expenditures for medical professional malpractice insurance is provided under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit for medical malpractice insurance expenditures is determined based on the applicable percentage of qualified expenses incurred by eligible persons in taxable years 2003 and 2004. The applicable percentage varies depending on the category of the eligible person, with percentages set at 20%, 10%, and 15% for different groups. The term 'eligible person' includes physicians in various specialties, hospitals, and clinics that meet legal requirements to provide healthcare services. 'Qualified medical malpractice insurance expenditure' refers to professional insurance costs. The term 'eligible person' includes physicians, hospitals, and clinics meeting legal requirements for healthcare services. 'Qualified medical malpractice insurance expenditure' refers to insurance costs incurred for general medical malpractice liability insurance, not exceeding twice the Statewide average for similarly situated eligible persons. The credit for this expenditure is claimed by the eligible person, with annual information provided by each State's board of medical licensure and insurance regulatory agency. The section requires insurance providers to submit necessary information to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for calculating average costs related to medical malpractice expenditures. This applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2002, and is part of the general business credit under the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment limits the carryback of the medical malpractice insurance expenditure tax credit before 2003 and denies a double benefit for medical malpractice liability insurance premiums. The amendment restricts the deduction for medical malpractice insurance expenditures by the amount of the credit allowable under section 45G. Controlled groups must follow specific rules. Grants are provided to non-profit hospitals and clinics by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services awards grants to eligible non-profit hospitals and clinics to help with medical malpractice insurance costs. Eligible entities must be non-profit, unable to claim a specific tax credit, and submit an application to the Secretary. The Secretary of Health and Human Services awards grants to non-profit hospitals and clinics for medical malpractice insurance costs. The grant amount equals 15 percent of the hospital or clinic's qualified medical malpractice insurance expenditures. Qualified expenditures include professional insurance premiums required for State licensure. The Secretary of Health and Human Services provides grants to non-profit hospitals and clinics for medical malpractice insurance costs, not exceeding twice the Statewide average. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2004 and 2005. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section provide a credit for expenditures on medical professional malpractice insurance, effective for expenses incurred after December 31, 2002.
